name: Reverse String
title: Reverse String
content:
Write a function that reverses a string. The input string is given as an array of characters s.

You must do this by modifying the input array in-place with O(1) extra memory.

 

Example 1:

Input: s = ["h","e","l","l","o"]
Output: ["o","l","l","e","h"]

Example 2:

Input: s = ["H","a","n","n","a","h"]
Output: ["h","a","n","n","a","H"]

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 105
  • s[i] is a printable ascii character.

discussion_posts.content: need more questions like this to build confidence

discussion_posts.name: juansymontano
discussion_posts.content:
"s.reverse()"

interviewer: "implement your own function, how about recursion"

*sweats*

This problem is a litmus test of whether or not a programmer will be replaced by chatgpt. This is not a test of our syntax.

discussion_posts.name: hukun01
discussion_posts.content:
There are basically two ways to solve this problem. 

One is to use a StringBuilder, another is to reverse the underlying char array. 

For C/C++ programmers, they may want to modify the input string if it's not constant, so to achieve O(1) space.

However, for Java programmers, I don't see any improvement beyond O(n) time and space. This is no different from reversing an integer array...What's the point here?

discussion_posts.name: fuxinwei
discussion_posts.content: I test with Python solution `s = s[::-1]` but it always got wrong. Does someone know the reason?
